newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - Jan 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - Jan 21.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Chinese political and business stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Beijing. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (8610) 6532-1921. Fax: (8610) 6532-4978.
Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Wu Yi says China's foreign trade volume is expected to reach $310 in 1997, up by 6.4 percent compared with last year.
Vice-minister of Finance Liu Jibin says China's T-bill issue system needs further reform, and cites problems in the secondary market.
The People's Bank of China, the central bank, pledges to speed up reform of its notes processing and handling systems.
An analysts says China's booming stock market is partly attributed to a fall in M2 growth and a rise in M1 growth in 1996.
The head of China's grain reserve administration Luo Zhiling says domestic grain prices will rise in 1997.
China will allocate some of its rapidly growing foreign reserves as seller's credit for power projects to buy domestic generating systems.
U.S.-based Hewlett-Packard Co captured an 11.4 percent share of China's personal computer market in 1996.
Sales of personal computers in China increased 56 percent to 1.8 million units.
Ningbo in eastern China's Zhejiang province handled 76.3 million tonnes of cargo in 1996, becoming the third largest seaport in China.
China cracked 230,000 economic crimes involving nearly 10 billion yuan ($1.2 billion) in 1996.
